sec.title: Preliminaries
sec.p: A continuous real random variable ZZ is said to follow a generalised hyperbolic secant distribution (GHS) (Harkness and Harkness 1968) with parameter \lambda>0λ>0 if the corresponding probability density function can be written as:
where \Gamma(w)Γ(w) is the Gamma function in the complex plane, that is
The name of the distribution comes from the case \lambda=1λ=1, e.g.
which can be obtained by using identity 6.1.30 in Abramowitz and Stegun (1964).
Using the properties of the complex Gamma function (Section 6.1 in Abramowitz and Stegun (1964)) we can write the log densities as follows:

\log g(z|\lambda) = (\lambda-2)\log(2)-\log(\pi)-\log \Gamma(\lambda)+ 2\,Re\left(\log \Gamma\left(\frac{\lambda}{2}+i\frac{z}{2}\right)\right) logg(z|λ)=(λ−2)log(2)−log(π)−logΓ(λ)+2Re(logΓ(λ2+iz2)) To compute g(z|\lambda)g(z|λ) we only need a function to evaluate the log of the Gamma function in the complex plane and here we use the gls package (Hankin (2006)) to do so.
The densities g(z|\lambda)g(z|λ) are symmetric about zero (see Figure 1) with exponentially decaying tails.
The moment generating function of the GHS distribution is well defined and is given by:

The above implies the GHS distribution is infinitely divisible so that the probability distribution of independent sums of GHS distributions is also a GHS distribution. Then any GHS distribution with integer \lambdaλ can be reproduced by convolutions of the basic density with \lambda=1λ=1.
The distribution has zero mean and the parameter \lambdaλ that equals the variance.
In this way, the standard distribution is g(z|1)g(z|1). The natural exponential family (NEF) generated by the GHS distribution has therefore densities of the form:
By making the transformation Y=Z/\lambdaY=Z/λ we obtain the so-called exponential family form (see McCullagh and Nelder (1989))

where \psi(\theta)=\log(\sec(\theta))ψ(θ)=log(sec(θ)). This is a reproductive exponential dispersion model in the language of Jorgensen (1997) and \phi=1/\lambdaϕ=1/λ is the so-called dispersion parameter. Clearly, if \lambdaλ is unknown then \tilde{f}_Y(y|\theta,\lambda)f̃Y(y|θ,λ) is not a two-dimensional exponential family.
We will follow Morris (1982) and call the family \tilde{f}_Y(y|\theta,\lambda)f̃Y(y|θ,λ) the NEF-GHS. The mean and variance of the NEF-GHS are given by:
We can reparametrise in terms of the mean \muμ and the dispersion parameter \phi=1/\lambdaϕ=1/λ as follows
Form the above we obtain that g(\mu)=\arctan(\mu)g(μ)=arctan(μ) is the corresponding canonical link of the family.

nef_ghs<-gaussian()
nef_ghs$family = "nef ghs" nef_ghs$link = "arctan" nef_ghs$linkfun = function(mu)atan(mu) # canonical link function nef_ghs$linkinv = function(eta)tan(eta) # inverse link function nef_ghs$variance = function(mu) 1+mu^2 nef_ghs$mu.eta = function(eta) sec(eta)^2 # Derivative of mean wrt eta nef_ghs$dev.resids = function(y, mu,wt){2*wt*y(atan(y)-atan(mu))+log((1+mu^2)/(1+y^2))} # Deviance residuals nef_ghs$aic = function(y, mu, weights, data) 1 # AIC nef_ghs$validmu = function(mu) is.finite(mu) # Valid mu nef_ghs$valideta = function(eta) abs(eta)<pi/2 nef_ghs$dispersion = 1
str(nef_ghs)
